Dialogue: This story takes place in its own universe. It has no connection to any of the DC films that have come before it.  We see it as a classic Warner Bros. movie. Gritty, intimate and oddly funny, the characters live in the real world and the stakes are personal.  Although it is never mentioned in the film, this story takes place in the past.  Let's call it 1981.  It's a troubled time. The crime rate in Gotham is at record highs. A garbage strike has crippled the city for the past six weeks. And the divide between the "haves" and the "have- nots" is palpable. Dreams are beyond reach, slipping into delusions.

Dialogue: Yes. But they wouldn't let me in, wouldn't let me see you. So I came here. I have so many questions.

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: Look pal, I'm not your father. What's wrong with you?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: Cause you were adopted. And I never fucked your mother. What do you want from me, money?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No. What? I wasn't adopted.

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: She never told you? Your mother adopted you before she even started working for us. She was arrested when you were four years old and committed to Arkham State Hospital. She's batshit crazy.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No. No, I don't believe that.

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: I don't really give a shit   what you believe.  But if you ever come to my   house again, if you ever talk to   my son again, if I ever even hear   about you again, I'll--

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: Are you laughing at me?

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: You think this is funny?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No, no I have a con--

Speaker: thomas wayne
Dialogue: Is this a fucking joke to you?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Sophie?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Sorry for the wait. All our records that are 10 years or older are stored in the basement. You're talking over 30 years ago,-- I had to do some serious digging.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Like I said, if it's in here, I'm still gonna need a release from her.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Can I ask you a question? How does someone wind up in here? Have all these people committed crimes?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Some have. Some are just crazy and pose a danger to themselves or others. Some just got nowhere else to go.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah, I know how that is. Sometimes I don't know what to do, y'know, I don't think I can take any more of this.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yeah, I can't take much more of this shit either.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Last time I ended up taking it out on some,-- people. Bad shit. I thought it would bother me but, it really hasn't.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: It's just so hard to try and be happy all the time, y'know, when everything's going to shit all around you.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Listen, I'm just an administrative assistant, like a clerk. I file paperwork, fill out forms. I don't really know what to tell you, but maybe you should see someone-- they have programs, like city services.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah. They cut those. Anyway, I was just talking to talk.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Here it is,-- Fleck. Penny Fleck.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: So she was a patient here.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Uh-huh. Diagnosed by Dr. Benjamin Stoner... The patient suffers from delusional psychosis and narcissistic personality disorder... Found guilty of endangering the welfare of a child--

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Besides, it's pretty bad.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I can handle bad. I've been on a pretty bad run myself.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I can't help you. If you want these records you have to get your mom to sign a patient disclosure form. I can have someone mail you one.

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: What the hell was that? You can't just walk into my apartment like that.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No, wait,-- Sophie, we can get through this, that's why I'm here.

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: What are you talking about? What do you think this is?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I don't know. I mean I've never been with a woman "like that," but, this feels like a beginning to me.

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: Arthur, I was just being nice to you. I felt sorry for you. I have a boyfriend.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: You what? What? What kind of woman are you? Who does that?

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: You need to leave. I'm not having this conversation with you.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: Go back with your friends, honey. Mommy's having a grown up talk.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No. Don't listen to her GiGi, you need to hear this. Your mother's a bad person. She's a whore, she's seeing two men at once. You can't trust her,-- She'll break your fucking heart.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: How come nothing ever comes easy for me?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Ma, remember how you used to tell me that God gave me this laugh for a reason. That I had a purpose. To bring laughter and joy into this fucked up world,--

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: HA! It wasn't God, it was you or, or one of your boyfriends,-- how could you let that happen? What kind of woman are you? What kind of mother are you?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: What's my real name?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: C'mon, Ma, I know I was adopted. What's my name? Who am I really?

Speaker: mom
Dialogue: H-h-happ--

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: But you know what's funny? You know what really makes me laugh?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I used to think my life was nothing but a tragedy, but now, now I realize it's all just a fucking comedy.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah, I don't know if I should cross or uncross 'em. Both feel completely unnatural.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Thanks for having me on, Murray. I can't tell you how much this means to me, it's been a life long dream. I have a joke for you--

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: You're right. You're right, uncrossed is better.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: You shouldn't be here. It's not right.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: It's always been just me and her.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: You saw that?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah, well I guess you didn't get the joke.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Which hospital?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I just buried my mother.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Right. Thanks for coming.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: That was a joke.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Hey Arthur, how's it going? You get a new gig?

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: You must be goin' down to that rally at City Hall. Right? I hear it's gonna be nuts.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Is that today?

Speaker: randall
Dialogue: Yeah. What's with the clown-face then?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: My mom died.

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: What the fuck what the fuck WHAT THE FUCK--

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I'm gonna be on TV tonight. Can you believe it?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: It's okay, Gary. You can go.

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: --You gotta see this nut for yourself, Murray. I don't think we can put him on. With the rioting out there.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Jesus, Gene, I don't have time for this. Cindy's been breaking my balls all day.

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: She's still mad at you about that thing?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Three marriages, you'd think I'da fuckin' learned something.  What do I gotta see? I already know he's a nut. That's why we're putting him on, it's a goof.

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: I'm telling you, you gotta see him, Murray. I think it's too risky, the show's too big. It's worth too much to blow it on this,-- this freak.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Murray, I can't believe this is real, that I'm really here.

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: It's Mr. Franklin kid, show some respect.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Oh shut up, Gene.  Murray is fine. I prefer it in fact. Thanks for coming on the show.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Are you kidding? Thank you for the opportunity. I've been watching you forever. My mother never missed a show.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: So what's with the face? Are you part of the protests?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No, I don't believe in any of that. I don't believe in anything. I just thought it would be good for my act.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No. I hadn't heard.

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: --the audience is gonna go crazy if you put him on. It was okay maybe for a bit, but not a whole segment.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: I like it. It's timely. It's edgy. It's, it's dangerous. The best comedy is all those things put together.  We're gonna go with it.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Thank you Murray.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Couple rules though,-- No cussing, no off-color material, we do a clean show, okay? You'll be on after Dr. Sally. Someone will come and get you. Good?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Hey Murray,-- one small thing? When you bring me out, can you introduce me as "The Joker"?

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: What? You don't want to use your real name?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Honestly, I don't even know what my real name is.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Besides, that's what you called me on the show, Murray. A joker. Remember?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Did I?

Speaker: gene ufland
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Well, if you say so, kid. Joker it is.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: You gotta see our next guest for yourself. Will you stick around? Maybe you can help, I'm pretty sure he could use a doctor.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: He looks like he's got a lot of problems.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: It's been a crazy few days here in Gotham, and, I think maybe things are about to get crazy around here too. Don't go anywhere folks. We'll be right back.

Speaker: associate producer
Dialogue: Back in 30 seconds.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Okay, cue the clip. We'll come to it straight out of break.

Speaker: associate producer
Dialogue: Five... Four... Three...

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Roll clip. Put up the show graphic.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: O-kay, you may have seen that clip of our next guest when we first played it two weeks ago. Now before he comes out, I just want to say that we're all heartbroken here and sensitive to what's going on in the city tonight. But, this is how he wanted to come on the show. So let me introduce-- The Joker.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: So, ahhh, thanks for coming on the show. But I gotta tell ya, with what happened at City Hall today, I'm sure many of our viewers here in the studio, and at home, might find this look of yours in poor taste.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Can you tell us why you're dressed like this?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Okay. But I'm not sure how any of this is funny. A lot of those protesters are going with this look. City seems to be full of clowns these days.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah. Isn't it great?

Speaker: technical director
Dialogue: This guy's got nothing.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Gene, what the hell? You wanna kill this?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: So when we talked earlier, you mentioned that you aren't political. That this look isn't a political statement.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: That's right. I'm not political, Murray. I'm, I'm, I'm just trying to make people laugh.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: How's that goin' for ya? Have you been working on any new material? Do you want to tell us a joke?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: You brought a joke book?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Okay. Here's one. Knock knock.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Oh god, a knock-knock joke? And you need to read it?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I want to get it right. Knock knock.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: It's the police, ma'am. Your son has been hit by a drunk driver. He's dead.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Okay, ready Camera Two. Take Two. Ready Three. Three.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Right. Sorry. I mean Joker-- you told me backstage that your mother's a big fan of the show, that she never misses it.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: That's right, Murray. But she's dead now.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Hold on. Your mother's dead?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah. She is.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Okay. What about your father? Does he watch the show?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I don't know who my father is, Murray. Turns out I was adopted and sexually assaulted by my mother's boyfriend.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Yeah, that's not funny, that's not the kind of humor we do on this show.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Sorry. It's been a rough few months, Murray. I mean, after my mother died, the police came to question me at her funeral. Who does that?

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Oh really? Were you a suspect?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Very funny, Murray. No, they came because I killed those three Wall Street guys.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Okay. I'm waiting for the punchline.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: There is no punchline. It's not a joke.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Did he just confess to killing the Wall Street Three?

Speaker: technical director
Dialogue: Yeah. I think he did.

Speaker: associate producer
Dialogue: He definitely did.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Jesus Christ.  Camera Three, get in close.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: You're serious, aren't you? You're telling us you killed those three boys on the subway. Why should we believe you?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I got nothing left to lose, Murray. Nothing can hurt me anymore. This is my fate, it was always my fate. My life is nothing but a comedy.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Okay, I think I understand. You did it to start a movement, to become a symbol.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: C'mon, Murray, do I look like the kind of clown who could start a movement? I killed those guys because they were awful. Everybody's awful these days. It's enough to make anyone crazy.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: So that's it, you're crazy. That's your defense for killing three young men? Because they were mean to you?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: No. They couldn't carry a tune to save their lives.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Yeah. I do. Everything comes so easy for him.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: And what's wrong with that?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Have you seen what it's like out there, Murray? Do you ever actually leave the studio? Everybody just yells and screams at each other. Nobody's civil anymore. Nobody thinks what it's like to be the other guy. You think men like Thomas Wayne, men at ease, ever think what it's like to be a guy like me? To be anybody but themselves.  They don't. They think we'll all just sit there and take it like good little boys. That we won't werewolf and go wild. Well, this is for all of you out there.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: You're awful, Murray.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: Me? How am I awful?

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: Playing my video, inviting me on the show,-- You just wanted to make fun of me. Well it's easy to laugh at Frankenstein on a crowded beach, isn't it? You're just like the rest of them, Murray. Everything comes too easy for you.

Speaker: murray franklin
Dialogue: You don't know the first thing about me, pal. Look what happened because of what you did, Arthur, what it led to. There are riots out there. Two policemen are in critical condition, someone was killed today.

Speaker: joker
Dialogue: I'll tell you what you get. You get what you fucking deserve,--
